title: Ecommerce Conversion Rate: What's Good, What's Bad, and How to Fix It
excerpt: Your conversion rate is the multiplier on every dollar you spend on ads. Here's what the benchmarks actually look like and what to do if yours is falling short.
author: gabriel-lunesu

content.text: Conversion rate is the most leveraged metric in ecommerce. Every improvement in conversion rate makes every other metric better — your ROAS improves, your CAC drops, and your ad budget goes further without changing a single campaign. Yet most merchants spend the majority of their optimization time on ad platforms and very little on the store itself. This is where the leverage is.
What Ecommerce Conversion Rate Actually Measures

Ecommerce conversion rate = Purchases / Sessions, expressed as a percentage. If 100 people visit your store and 2 buy, your conversion rate is 2%. This sounds simple but there are important nuances. Shopify's default conversion rate includes all sessions — including people who arrive on your blog, your about page, or pages with no purchase intent. A more useful metric is add-to-cart conversion rate and checkout completion rate, which diagnose specific parts of your funnel.
What's a Good Ecommerce Conversion Rate?

The most commonly cited average for ecommerce is 1-3%. But this hides enormous variation by traffic source, product category, price point, and audience type. Retargeting traffic converts at 3-5x the rate of cold traffic. Organic search converts differently than paid social. A $20 impulse purchase converts at dramatically higher rates than a $500 considered purchase.

Rather than benchmarking against industry averages, benchmark against yourself. Track your conversion rate by traffic source over time. If your Meta ad traffic converts at 1.2% and it was 1.8% three months ago, something changed — and finding out what is more actionable than knowing where you stand relative to competitors.
The Most Common Conversion Rate Killers

Slow page speed is still the number one silent killer. Every additional second of load time reduces conversion rate measurably. Run your store through Google PageSpeed Insights and fix whatever it flags — heavy images, unused scripts, render-blocking resources. Mobile page speed matters more than desktop for most Shopify stores.

Weak product pages are close behind. A product page that doesn't answer the key objections (Will this fit? How long will it take? What if I don't like it?) loses sales that better copy and creative would have captured. Review your top-traffic product pages critically and ask: does this page give someone everything they need to decide with confidence?

Checkout friction is the third big one. Shopify's native checkout is already well-optimized, but unnecessary steps, required account creation, and limited payment options still kill conversions. Use Shop Pay where possible — it significantly reduces checkout abandonment.
How to Diagnose Your Conversion Funnel

Map your funnel: Sessions → Product page views → Add to carts → Checkout initiations → Purchases. Calculate the drop-off rate at each step. Where's the biggest leak? If you're losing most visitors between product page view and add-to-cart, your product page needs work. If you're losing them between add-to-cart and checkout, your cart or offer structure is the issue. If checkout initiation to purchase is low, look at payment options and checkout experience.
Testing That Actually Moves Conversion Rate

High-impact CRO tests for Shopify: product photography quality and quantity, product title and description rewrite, social proof placement (reviews above the fold), pricing and offer structure (bundles, free shipping thresholds), and hero image on homepage. Don't test button colors or minor copy tweaks until you've exhausted the big structural changes — the signal will be too small to measure reliably.
